AbstractText: Self‐assembled liposome microreactors mimic the spatial separation of redox reactions seen in respiration and photosynthesis. Catalytic reduction of the climate heating gas N<sub>2</sub>O to benign N<sub>2</sub> by encapsulated enzyme is driven by irradiation of external carbon dots through an electron transfer pathway defined by a membrane‐spanning cytochrome and redox‐cycling of internal methyl viologen.
OtherAbstract.CopyrightInformation: © 2022 The Authors. Angewandte Chemie published by Wiley-VCH GmbH.

Journal.Title: Angewandte Chemie (Weinheim an der Bergstrasse, Germany)

Article.ArticleTitle: Photocatalytic Removal of the Greenhouse Gas Nitrous Oxide by Liposomal Microreactors.

AbstractText: Nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O) is a potent greenhouse and ozone-reactive gas for which emissions are growing rapidly due to increasingly intensive agriculture. Synthetic catalysts for N<sub>2</sub>O decomposition typically contain precious metals and/or operate at elevated temperatures driving a desire for more sustainable alternatives. Here we demonstrate self-assembly of liposomal microreactors enabling catalytic reduction of N<sub>2</sub>O to the climate neutral product N<sub>2</sub>. Photoexcitation of graphitic N-doped carbon dots delivers electrons to encapsulated N<sub>2</sub>O Reductase enzymes via a lipid-soluble biomolecular wire provided by the MtrCAB protein complex. Within the microreactor, electron transfer from MtrCAB to N<sub>2</sub>O Reductase is facilitated by the general redox mediator methyl viologen. The liposomal microreactors use only earth-abundant elements to catalyze N<sub>2</sub>O removal in ambient, aqueous conditions.
Abstract.CopyrightInformation: © 2022 The Authors. Angewandte Chemie published by Wiley-VCH GmbH.
